IP32650-004_syn_2:
PROCEDURE: Right medical thoracoscopy with mechanical and chemical pleurodesis.
PATIENT: [REDACTED] (Decompensated Cirrhosis).
NARRATIVE: The right pleural space was accessed under general anesthesia. A massive transudative effusion (2100 mL) was evacuated. Inspection revealed smooth, glistening pleura consistent with hepatic hydrothorax; no gross malignancy was id[REDACTED]. To maximize the probability of symphysis in this difficult scenario, a combined approach was utilized: mechanical abrasion of the parietal pleura followed by instillation of 4 grams of talc slurry.
POST-OP: Patient transferred to step-down for hemodynamic monitoring and albumin replacement.

IP32650-004:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Medical thoracoscopy with talc pleurodesis for hepatic hydrothorax.
Patient: [REDACTED], 59-year-old male with decompensated cirrhosis and refractory right hepatic hydrothorax.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with single-lumen ETT.
Indication: Dyspnea and frequent hospitalizations for large right transudative pleural effusion despite sodium restriction and diuretics.
Procedure details: Ultrasound localization id[REDACTED] a large free-flowing right effusion. A 2 cm incision was made in the right 6th intercostal space, midaxillary line. After trocar insertion, 2.1 L of clear, straw-colored fluid was drained. Thoracoscopic inspection showed smooth parietal pleura without nodularity. No suspicious lesions were biopsied. Mechanical abrasion pleurodesis was performed using a thoracoscopic pad; 4 g of sterile talc in 100 mL saline was then distributed evenly. A 24 Fr chest tube was placed posteriorly.
Complications: Transient hypotension corrected with albumin bolus; no bleeding.
Estimated blood loss: 10 mL.
Disposition: Admitted to step-down unit for close monitoring of hemodynamics and chest tube output.
Plan: Albumin replacement for large volume drainage; chest tube to suction initially, then water seal; hepatology consultation regarding TIPS.
